children.subject: (same anon) by super time consuming I mean I spent 20+ hours a week on 70 homework, and when there was a 61C project too that would be a week of way too many hours in Soda/Cory (like the entire weekend and then some)

Have you looked at the course syllabi? They're all on their websites. I took 70 and 61C together, and mostly it's just super super super time consuming. But it depends on how much of the material you know already. I knew nothing before taking the courses, and needed to do well in 70, so it was stressful. But definitely doable, I mean. Just not very fun.
I would highly suggest a relatively easy semester when you take CS 61C. It is a hard, time consuming class.

history.content:
I haven't taken 61c, but ee16b was very painful for me with 70 (mind it, probably it was just last semester, but I have never felt tests so hard in any class I have taken ever). Now, ee is definitely not my best area so that might be related. The reason why I mostly disliked 16b and 70 together was because psets for 16b were due on Thursdays and 70 psets were due on Fridays. Because 16b (particularly the long ones) were conceptually difficult for me, it usually took me a long time to finish them, which lead me to have less time to devote to 70 psets. Then, luckily I never had midterms close to each other, but I felt that both classes required you to have a very deep grasp of everything. This said, in both cases (but especially surprisingly for me with Jaijeet in 16b) I felt that the tests were a long shot from the understanding that we got from lecture, section and psets (this mostly applies for 16b).

Now, I have heard terrible things about 61c + 70. If you are L&S CS it might be something you would likely want to avoid if you do not feel decently prepared for either. This is, however, a fairly common combination which many of my friends have taken (especially when the 3.0 cap was in place). It could be done, but it will definitely be hard, especially since, as of what I've heard, 61c is now including more projects and is a bit more intense. I would recommend you, given the conversations I've had with other friends, for you to take ee16b and 70 together instead of 61c + 70. The reason why is because 61c is hard and has a lot of work. 16b is very hard (I obviously cannot compare it with 61c) but it will certainly take you less time to succeed in 16b than in 61c and I feel that 2x psets + midterms is a better combo than psets + projects + midterms. Just make sure not to slack off because 16b is a very hard course compared to 16a (which, in my opinion, is arguably hard as well)

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I took EE16B+CS61B in Fall 2017 and CS70+CS61C this past Spring. In my experience, Spring semester was much easier to manage and more successful of the two class loads. This is mostly because 61C does not overload students with weekly homeworks and the 61C labs can more or less be completed within the 2 hour section. This ensured that the CS70 problem sets were given enough time during the week. Compare to 16B+61B, of which both classes assign weekly homeworks and weekly labs. I found myself juggling several weekly assignments at once.

61C offers exams that are relatively easy to study for (more memorization of facts than problem sets) at the expense of the 5 weeks of intense projects (a new project is assigned practically every week or every other week) . If you can manage the 5 week project period, 61C will be a breeze (if you keep up with lectures). This allows more time to focus on 70 during the week. 16B doesn't allow this kind of freedom ebcause each week brings a new abstract and very mathematical concept, which will take most students more than a week to fully grasp. Having to do intense comprehension for two very conceptual classes can prove to be cumbersome. Thus, I think 61C+70 allows a fair balance of abstract learning and applied projects.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I took CS70 + EE16B + CS170 together in Freshman year, and I actually enjoyed that semester as I like the materials from all of them. Also did Math 110 + EECS126 + CS188 in another semester, and I loved it too.

On the other hand, I was miserable in the semester where CS 61C is my only technical (I actually dropped my other technicals because 61C was that time-consuming). It was just not my cup of tea to spend countless hours debugging until you realize the code is off by one line.

So in short, "sadness and despair" is quite subjective. If you enjoy math, CS70 and EE16B should not be problem for you at all. But if you know C to some extend and are able to write code that is right on, CS61C would be a breeze.

Edit: I should have mentioned that I took CS70 with "TEST ONLY" option. The majority of my friends who did also well chose the same option.

I haven't taken 61c, but ee16b was very painful for me with 70 (mind it, probably it was just last semester, but I have never felt tests so hard in any class I have taken ever). Now, ee is definitely not my best area so that might be related. The reason why I mostly disliked 16b and 70 together was because psets for 16b were due on Thursdays and 70 psets were due on Fridays. Because 16b (particularly the long ones) were conceptually difficult for me, it usually took me a long time to finish them, which lead me to have less time to devote to 70 psets. Then, luckily I never had midterms close to each other, but I felt that both classes required you to have a very deep grasp of everything. This said, in both cases (but especially surprisingly for me with Jaijeet in 16b) I felt that the tests were a long shot from the understanding that we got from lecture, section and psets (this mostly applies for 16b).

Now, I have heard terrible things about 61c + 70. If you are L&S CS it might be something you would likely want to avoid if you do not feel decently prepared for either. This is, however, a fairly common combination which many of my friends have taken (especially when the 3.0 cap was in place). It could be done, but it will definitely be hard, especially since, as of what I've heard, 61c is now including more projects and is a bit more intense. I would recommend you, given the conversations I've had with other friends, for you to take ee16b and 70 together instead of 61c + 70. The reason why is because 61c is hard and has a lot of work. 16b is very hard (I obviously cannot compare it with 61c) but it will certainly take you less time to succeed in 16b than in 61c and I feel that 2x psets + midterms is a better combo than psets + projects + midterms. children.subject:
I took 61C + 70 together this spring 2018. 

It was not fun. 

The only good thing about it was that it was a nice combination of math problem sets and pure cs coding. 

The bad things:

1) The first midterm for each class was at the same time. So I had to take the 61c midterm from 9:30 pm - 11:30 pm :(

The second midterms were one day apart, and there was a 61c project due a few days after each midterm. It was very difficult to balance the midterms and assignments in the same week (plus I had a third midterm for a different class), and I did not manage my studying. Learn from my mistakes and make sure you don't ignore practice tests in favor of finishing all the assignments. 

2) Both classes are work heavy. There were 13 hw assignments in 70, each of which took me 8-12 hours each. There were 5 projects in 61c, two of which had 2 parts, so it was really like 7 projects. It was difficult to balance all the work. I was able to understand enough to finish the assignments at a bare minimum, but I had no time to really delve into a conceptual understanding, which hurt me on the exams. 

3) Both of these classes were conceptually difficult, and I did not have much interest in the material I was learning - I was taking these courses for requirements. The combination of hard + not interesting/motivating really fucks with your ability to cope with the stress. This may not apply to you if end up becoming more interested in the subject - for example, my fall schedule is as hard or arguably harder than what I took this past spring but the difference is that I am excited for these classes - I chose them. [also I appreciated the material I learned in 61c much more after I finished the class. It was hard to see the point of it all in the midst of the pure misery, but afterwards I was like "wow I actually know how a computer works now"]

I have not taken ee16b so I cannot comment on it

In all honesty, if you have the schedule flexibility, take 70 by itself without any other major tech class (except maybe math 54 - I think that would be doable but then again I LOVED 54). That way you can really put in the time the course deserves to understand and empathize with the material. 

If you don't have the flexibility (or just want to get the reqs over with like I did [I wholeheartedly regret that decision]) (or anticipate yourself adapting to the material well), then take mine and other classmates advice as you will.

I would highly recommend not taking 61C and 70 together. They’re both a ton of work (61C was the most challenging Lower div for me), and require a lot of deep knowledge in order to do well (as in, you can’t really BS your way through them). I took 70 and 16B together in the spring a year ago, and I found that 16B was a pretty light workload in comparison (especially if you’ve taken math 54 already). The EE series I also tended to do better in grade-wise.

I know these classes have changed since I took them though, with 61C potentially becoming less demanding(?), but regardless, since 70 and 61C are known to be the two harder lower divs, I’d avoid taking them together.

history.content:
I've heard from multiple sources and classmates that taking 70 and 61C together is a ticket to sadness and despair. Can y'all share why it was so difficult and how time consuming it was? 

Is taking CS70 and EE16B any easier than the previous combination and how difficult would that be?
history.subject: CS70 + CS61C vs CS70 + EE16B
